Row.Text: Abbasid scholars have gathered all the world's knowledge under their eyes. All the world's most brilliant minds will be part of their empire of learning.
Collect the most brilliant minds of the world!
The empire stands at the brink of new discoveries, and the world awaits.
Areas once thought unfit for human habitation now teem with life. Cities grow steadily into centers for commerce and learning, and travelers from abroad come to dream of such progress for themselves.

The Abbasids remember the power that the Egyptians found on the frontiers of their empire - where they had the relentless medjay, the Abbasids have the Mamluks - nomads brought into service under the Abbasid throne. Now, Abbasid power eyes lands long held and now lost.
Reclaim what once was Egypt that it might be Abbasid.
The steppe warriors overwhelm all would-be conquerors with their speed, bringing rich ransoms as reward.
Retake the captured Settlement with a Mamluk within {1_turn_timer}.
Scholars of faith discuss the need for an expansion of knowledge, a place for officials to be educated and spread their religious teachings to the youth.
A center for secular learning needs to be built.
The completed madrasa is an architectural marvel ready for scholars and students alike to populate its courtyard with lively discussions about faith.
Our scholars consider carefully the role of our faith and expand our knowledge. Our people, on the other hand, are our very heart and soul. But they often do not agree.
Let us finish our efforts to comfort our people.
We have built a house of faith.

The people were once of the desert, learning how to bring water and life to areas that seemed unfit for habitation. Now, cities blossom into centers of commerce and learning, drawing travelers from far and wide who come to dream of such progress for themselves.

The shelves are mostly filled. The scholars’ residences are completed. Scribes await their tasks. But the scholars do not appear, and books set for Abbasid shores move elsewhere. Still, the people pledge to persevere.
The bells toll, and Notre Dame opens her doors. Stony saints peer from alcoves as the masses gaze at lofty vaults.

Camels are a crucial part of the fabric of travel and transit, and the variety in their personalities is much-discussed by their handlers. Some of the beasts are particularly recalcitrant biters and spitters.
Consign difficult camels to the menagerie.
Sell bad camels to the unwitting.

In the cloister of Lone Tree Abbey, an illuminated manuscript has been discovered full of incredibly naughty drawings, done by an anonymous hand. The monks are abuzz about who the culprit might be, and certainly not about the contents of the pages themselves.
Ravens cackle as a local bishop is led in chains into the newly built White Tower. He is the dungeon's first prisoner… but not for long. In the dead of night, he slips past the guards to freedom.
The tower's defenses must be strengthened.
As the final stone is laid, bells sound across the city and banners unfurl on the ramparts. The castle is complete! A faire is organized to celebrate its makers...

A newly discovered passion for truffle-hunting has led to some heated disputes among rural folk. Truffles thrive in secret places, but are so valuable that many demand to know the locations of their neighbors' closely guarded patches.
Truffle sites should be kept secret.
Hunters must collaborate on a truffle map.

Smoke rises from destroyed buildings as scholars flee the onslaught of Songhai might. What value is education if it cannot combat swords? Yet as the soldiers pick through the academic debris, they find strange trinkets of gold, inventions of the scholars. These will fetch a pretty price. Perhaps there is value to learning after all.
A diver has recovered a massive shark's tooth, as big as a human hand. Weaponsmiths claim this tooth would create the ultimate leiomano, while craftspeople eye its keen edge.
A military engineer recommends the use of explosive ammunition in trebuchets. Many consider this a breakthrough in military technology, though his friends warn of gaps in his sanity.

A mysterious hunting hound has been glimpsed in the forest, said to be as vibrantly opalescent in color as the sea. An old woodcutter exhorts to his wife about the dog from Elfland, but she scoffs and sighs: dyed dogs are simply a popular fashion these days, she says.
Offerings shall be left to the dog from Elfland!
The royal hounds shall be dyed in kind.

As war rages, the örtöö system of relay stations expedites the movement of both information and supplies. The reduction in travel time across the empire attracts the interest of merchants, who see potential upsides for themselves.
Merchants may use the system, for a price.
The service should be free to civilians.
Explorers find a letter on the dusty roadside. It reads: "This letter hath come direct from God! If it be copied and passed along, fortune be thine. If not, curses upon thee!"
Pass the letter on at once!
Incur the risk of a curse.

All remove their shoes when entering the mosque. But sometimes shoes go missing by the time the service is over. Complaints of theft continue to rise, but those caught wearing others' footwear claim they merely took the wrong pair by mistake.
Institute a fine for shoe thieves.
Provide spare shoes at the mosque.

Tall blond warriors from the land of Gog and Magog arrive in the capital on camels, offering Frankish swords and furs to trade in the Abbasid markets. The weapons are of the highest quality, while their furs will keep the people warm and fashionable.

There's an ancient tale about the rise of an exiled king and his battle against an evil sorcerer, but not everyone can agree on its interpretation. Griots argue from the perspective of myth, while scholars insist their view is backed by years of study.
There is deep truth in the griot's song.
The old texts support the scholarly version.
A peasant is brought into custody for hunting rabbits in the royal forest. On his knees, the poor man prays for mercy. His family is starving, he insists.
Offer amnesty to those in need.

The hospital is practically at capacity in the wake of the recent disaster, and there's no shortage of patients who need help. A leading doctor suggests that now is the ideal time to try new medical techniques on the injured in the hopes of advancing their care. But the overworked hospital staff fear that learning on the job will slow crucial care processes and risk lives.
In times of crisis, the future is made.
For now, the known is more reliable.

Citizens are determined to preserve the sacred memories of Uluru as urban development spreads. Sitting on her doorstep, an elderly woman shares the story of the Mala and their flight from the hound Kurpany. She is interrupted by a gang of children reenacting the battle of the serpents atop Uluru.
Popularize the legend of the Mala.
Embrace the story of the snakes.

At dusk, the desert dunes grow pink beneath the setting sun, and figures of sorcerers cast long shadows across the sand. They weave magic intended to ease the labor of workers, and to enhance the bounty of the harvest.
The workers can now work harder.
In the wake of the recent disaster, wealthy merchants still have an eye to their profits. Several are petitioning for relief from taxes, claiming special circumstances.
Tax amnesty for merchants should be discussed.

The negotiations between merchant groups and city financiers are far more fraught than expected. Eventually the merchants are able to secure some amount of relief from taxation in the wake of the recent disaster.
As negotiations break down about taxation in the wake of disaster, some of the merchants are found to have concealed their profits in an attempt to avoid their burden.
Onlookers cheer the strong builders as the final stone is placed for the new city wall. This is now the third wall waiting to be staffed by guards, but citizens feel much more secure.
Hire guards for the existing infrastructure.
Order the construction of more walls.
Seated comfortably before the nobles, the city official is practically impudent in his fine shimmering robe. He has come, he announces, to demand a voice. The nobles exchange flat glances.
Set up city councils for the burghers.
The upcoming secular festival planning has grown so opulent in scale that the priesthood is starting to demand some involvement.
Collect a tithe from the festival.
Keep religion out of the festival.
The interloper falls to our shark-toothed blade. He lies face-down, dark blood leaking into the sandy soil.
Take this lesson on the enemy's weakness.
A monk pens a wondrous bestiary of all the sea's creatures. The lengthiest entry is devoted to details of all the fish-men he claims to have personally encountered in his days as a sailor.
How much wine is stored at that monastery?

The abundance of cats attracted to the wharf by the smell of fish is becoming controversial among locals. The priests say scavenging for scraps at the dock is beneath such sacred creatures, but the local merchants say the cats' presence keeps food stores safe from rats.

Impossibly, the arquebusier is felled by a crossbow bolt – his last expression before collapsing face-down in the dirt is one of shock. The rangers advance, kicking aside firearms as they reload their reliable bows and prepare for the next volley.

The handsome singer, freed from his shackles, steps into the sunlight, savoring the sensation of liberation and shaking off the specter of death. Hand in hand with the woman who freed him, they walk together toward the next chapter of their lives.

A wealthy woman in all her finery begs the jailer on her knees for the life of a man. She heard his voice floating up from a small dungeon window, singing a song of love and loss, and found him imprisoned for avenging his brother. The final verse of his song gladly accepts death as the cost for his noble act. The overwhelmed jailer consults his patchwork memory of the law...
His sentence can be converted to military service.
He can be taken into this woman's custody.
The stars above the mountain peaks glitter like chips of glass. Scientists' feet crunch on the snow, but their eyes are trained upwards.
The astronomers will learn to deal with the cold, year-round.
It shall be used for royal events.

For many architects, a journey to the capital is the main gateway to new construction methods. But for city-states, these visits can be challenging to fund given the amount of tribute they must send to the palace.

The rich scent of incense leads two knights into a brightly lit chamber in the depths of a cave. At the center stands a remarkably beautiful woman with a golden crown on her head – but up close, her robes feel like stone, not silk. She is merely a statue. "Fair Isolde," says one knight, "forever out of reach!"
Such a beautiful statue should be more widely displayed.
This love is a private affair.

The Colosseum looms large in the landscape, an awe-inspiring reminder of the games of old. These days, artisans petition to use the space for their vast workshops, but displaced communities are already sheltering within its vaults.

The warriors' victory inspires pride among the citizens. Many claim the strength of the army comes from its ancient legacy, and arrange a celebration for their heroes before the Tomb of Askia. The youth beg to hear new stories of war, interrupting the griots as they sing tales of old.

Controversy engulfs the library at El Escorial. A few librarians have decided to move all the bookcases from their usual orientation perpendicular to the windows, instead placing them along the walls. The new set-up welcomes more light into the space, supposedly.
This is how it should be.
A knight of the court is said to have forged a bond with a ferocious lion. The beast is alternately feared and admired by all who see the duo.
Keep the lion with the army.
Such a beast should be in the menagerie.
Local rumors say that a mo'o dwells in the depths of a nearby pond, guarding and nurturing the pool's life. Those who come to the waterside say a mysterious silence falls over them.
Offer rainwater in a sacred bowl.
Offer local fruits on a handmade altar.

Locals leave bowls of rainwater by the silent pond to thank the mo'o for watching over the waters. One night, they claim to see a beautiful woman by the docks. Her pearly lizard's tail glistens in the rising moonlight. Under her care, they say, the fish are fat and plentiful.
A small gecko has been spotted eating fruit left on the shore by locals wishing to honor the mo'o. Since its appearance, they report good fortune and better harvests.
The earth trembles as the chevaler rides down his foe. The rider's steel arcs through the air, and the slower enemy stumbles and lies still.
The peasants will be inspired to take up arms.
The Songhai quest for gold is not only about wealth, but about the fruits of the imagination. What to do with all that glitters?
Invite artisans to create new gold works.
Share the wealth among the people.

The new menagerie has many wonderful creatures on display, and a visiting scholar is inspired to begin work on an illustrated bestiary. Such a catalog will surely draw more visitors to the menagerie, but some wonder if there are really enough animals there to fill an entire manuscript.
Invest in the scholar's bestiary work.

The talk of the capital is a new illustrated bestiary cataloging every menagerie animal, offering up juicy and obscure facts that draw more traffic to local attractions. This boom in enthusiasm around an academic work has great potential.
Attract more tourists to the menageries.
In a seaside pub, an old fisherman tells tales of a white whale. It sounds impossible, more madness of the sea. Yet many who hear it find their hair stands on end.
This whale must be hunted, at any cost.

At long last, whalers spot a shadow in the sea – one that grows lighter and lighter the closer it gets to the surface. Impossibly, the white whale of legend breaches the waves, and chaos breaks out on deck.
The men at arms stand in triumph amid the desolated village, though the beating sun of the desert afternoon is starting to make ovens of their armor. There may yet be gold in the empty buildings.
They must press on and find wealth.
They should not risk their lives.
Adventure and riches await abroad, but many citizens remain more comfortable at home. From old foundations, new ideas take flight – crafted, and funded, by the rising middle class.
The time is ripe for scientific breakthroughs.

A new artists' guild has taken to painting working people – farmers in their fields, blacksmiths at their anvils, carpenters at their saws. These subjects are delighted to be captured hard at work for all to see. But they are so busy that they have no time to view the finished products.
A cultural holiday is in order.
Those with time to see art have the money to pay for it.
The keshig guard marches down the field in formation. They are battle-tested and eager for war, awaiting the command of their general. Where will their conquest begin?
The rural settlements shall be overrun.
The town's inhabitants surrender before the keshig, coughing as the air fills with smoke from their burning homes. Above their bowed heads, black spirit banners wave in the wind.
Cities will be turned to ash.

Through once-peaceful farms and once-bustling streets, the keshig overrun the city. The hoofbeats of their horses herald the arrow's whistle, the flash of steel, and the ravenous flames that send smoke and screams to the Eternal Sky.

The Songhai warriors loot the caravan as the merchants flee, their cries echoing in the evening breeze. The fear of their victims cheers the unit as they bear their spoils back to the capital, but international relations suffer for their enthusiasm.
Gold Bangles receive 20% Pillage Bonus on Buildings and Improvements.
It's Not a Phase, It's a Lifestyle

The growth of the aristocracy induces an age of fancy parties. On festival days, the pavilion booms late into the night with music and dancing, and wine-giddy lords and ladies now seem to be extending their revelry for days on end. Surely this will have some effect on productivity, the politicians say.
The pavilion must be open every day!

The crowd roars and the Mamluk holds his sword high, soaking in the praise. The enemy lies defeated, and as more troops rush to challenge him, he sinks into stance and glares at them through the haze of battle. With the civilians rapt to his performance, the Mamluk knows that his future holds only victory.
He will be a legend to his people.
His victory and the empire's are one.

Hunters have heard howling in the night, and some claim to have glimpsed a massive, hairy creature ambulating among the trees. Legends begin to grow of a mysterious new species, though most believe it's probably just a particularly large bear.

The excited hunters embark on their search for the legendary Bigfoot. After tracking something monster-sized for days, they see a large hairy beast lurking on the hillside...a very large bear. Its meat and hide are valuable nonetheless.
Some may be skeptical about Bigfoot's existence, but sightings continue to be reported of a massive two-legged recluse living somewhere in the deepest woods.

An old treatise on music is unearthed in a forgotten university collection. It includes a song by a famous musician, noted by the author as the best in his craft. Perhaps the song would be just as impressive today, although the main intention of the text seems to be philosophical.

Fierce allegiance to sports teams has transformed fan clubs into political parties. Strong rivalries carry on within the government based on deep and valued traditions, though these conflicts often still turn to violence.

New traders come to Songhai, spreading out wares from faraway lands on elegant carpets. They retreat out of sight as the locals approach, letting them shop in peace. When the merchants return, they find payments left in place of absent items, and take note of how much these hard-earned treasures are worth here.
Offer market space to traders from abroad.
A golden age dawns, and the Vedas shine out to the world.
Send out wisdom on the trading vessels.
Others may claim the earth, but the empire that claims the sea stands strong on wooden shores, a floating land all their own.
Have 3 Trade Routes to Distant Lands.
The voyages of the mind come first.
The priests say the very engine of creation itself worked for days, then rested.
So too shall the people rest.
The people can endure even more than the divine.
Lately, envoys return from their dealings with smaller powers wearing frowns. The expansion in relations has been lucrative, but the more deals they cut, the less profitable each seems to be.
As long as the envoys are loyal.
As long as the money comes in.
The envoys set off, ready to receive tribute from the lesser states. Each merchant is inspired on their journey by a vision of their place, their important role in the Majapahit Empire.
Their true calling is to spread love of their sovereign.
They are profit's own golden hands.
Their voices tell of the glory that is Majapahit.
Under the Spanish flag, envoys depart for those who rightfully see us as their sovereign.
They will teach the world to love their leader.
They will collect the finest tributes from those who owe.
While an inn is the place for conversations to brew, one must pick the right facilitator for conversation to flow.
The richness of cocoa sets a casual tone.
Tea inspires a more refined discussion.
Abbasid philosophers continue their debates into the dark of night, fueled by steaming cups of coffee.
Songhai merchants discuss the latest prices over copper mugs of thick black coffee.
The students sit in rows, dressed in uniforms, eyes facing the teacher. He looks down at his lecture notes.
Equip students with a critical analysis of power.

A visiting priest is shocked to find a stone statue of a local deity standing outside the mine. An old miner calls it the earth's Grandfather, placing a small roll of tobacco between the statue's fingers: "If he is happy, we are happy," the miner says.
Take local customs and incorporate them into a greater vision.
{1_reward} on your Settlements following your Religion.

The man, wrapped in an orange cloak and with a white beard that reaches to his belly, wanders through the streets. Where there is someone hungry, he feeds them. Where there is someone cold, he clothes them. The people remember his words...
"The truly religious man is he who sees all as equals." - Guru Nanak
"The world is a drama, staged in a dream." - Guru Nanak
"Death would not be called bad, if only we knew how to die." - Guru Nanak

A grown child hesitates before entering his parents' house, the family altar neglected. The ancient temple's congregation is thinning, and ancient rites neglected as the next generation turns toward a new faith.
This is an assault on the old ways.
The old and the new must be combined.
A noble comes beseechingly before the council, weary-eyed with hat in hand. His serfs have taken their tools and abandoned him, he claims, to work more prosperous lands.
Nobles rule over land, not people. His workers are lost to him.
The workers remain the noble's subjects wherever they go.

An envoy encounters new believers, people who wear spiral tattoos in an unfamiliar language that only their initiated can read. One such believer invites an envoy to the cave where they claim the sacred texts are kept.
The envoy's work is to see and learn.
Though it stands on a far shore, the new kiln brings a steady stream of profits in, and also enriches the lands abroad.
Its value is in the gold it brings in.
It is more important to share our aesthetic values.
A cluster of braided oak leaves waits to be placed on the brow of this year's champion of the faith. The nominees rise and approach the ecumenical council seat, awaiting the final judgment.
Award a holy scholar dedicated to writing.
Recognize a crusader's commitment to holy war.

The city sees the rise of a new class: business owners who do not travel, but broker and grow their power locally. They have no titles, no manners, and no distinction save their wealth – and their certainty that they alone can see through history's cobwebs to the rational world.

In meals in well-appointed guildhalls, in the mezzanine of theaters, in hunting-lodge weekends – here is where the networks of global capital come together. It will be a rational and heartless world, but some will become rich.
Build a Guildhall in Distant Lands.
Make them pay tribute all the same.
The city-state representative's personal style shocks the court, accustomed to more quotidian visitors. But her desire to serve the people seems as strong as her dress is unfamiliar.
The galleon Mercy has met its fate at the bottom of the sea. But we can learn from its poor construction, and do better.
The followers of Guru Nanak are plentiful now in the city streets. Some seem concerned that the presence of a new faith will disrupt the security of the old.
{1_reward} on your Settlements following your Religion.
Animal pelts have become so vital to the economy that in some areas, "furs" just means "money." But trappers have a culture all their own, elusive and hard to pin down.
Introduce regular taxation and regulation to the fur trade.
Let the trappers continue on their own initiative.

One night, a much-loved pig lets loose an alarmed grunt, a flavor of squeal never heard before. As the staff investigates his reaction, they find a poisoner has been at work in their sovereign's dinner.
Pigs have an important role to play in food safety!

A beloved cow breaks loose from her enclosure on palace grounds, goring a passerby. She has never done such a random act of violence – and an inspection of the victim reveals them to be an assassin sent to infiltrate the palace.
All key staff must now have cows to guard them!
The calm of night is broken by the sharp, alarmed bark of a dog. Straining at his lead, he leads the guards to a palace intruder.

In the wake of the recent raid, rumors of assassins abound. Warriors of the keshig night guard sharpen their weapons, ready to sacrifice themselves for their ruler at a moment's notice. Their commander recommends increased security at the palace, but worried citizens beg for additional patrols in the city streets.
Double the watch at the palace.
The caravanserai hosts many travelers, and its coffers are overflowing. The priests request donations to enhance their nearby temple, but the local charity wishes to feed the poor.
Send the money to the temple.
Offer the funds to the charity.

Intellectuals from distant lands flock to Abbasid cities to avail themselves of legendary local knowledge. Opportunities for sharing research with newcomers abound, although surely some are suspicious of practices from abroad.
The new mathematical treatise Al-Jabr takes Abbasid scholarship to new heights, lighting the fire of competition in other disciplines. There are plentiful funding applications to consider.
Young children watch the night sky as elders weave tales of the early settlements. Their stories always end with a lesson on the Inca's new path, and how they came to it.

The growth of the Inca inspires artists to capture the changing world around them. Some draw inspiration from the lush fertility of the terrace farms, while others imagine the far-off lands described by returning chasquis.

As Inca roads stretch beyond the horizons, new voices join the chorus of the empire, many of them chanting to new gods. Communities begin to combine their traditions, but the high priests fear it will be complex to officially expand their pantheon.

Scholars traveling to the capital hear strange music as they rest in their tents. A low tone accompanies a higher harmonic, capturing the sound of the wind dancing in the landscape. The captivated scholars follow the voice as it rises and falls among the hills, until they find a nomadic herder serenading his flock.
Sponsor the art of Khöömei at court.
Leave the music to its wild roots.

As Mongol influence spreads, nobles converse about new painting styles, exemplified by two recent works. One is a contemporary portrait of a court lady, resplendent in a red boqta. The other resurrects a coarser style in his painting of a man and his horse on a windy day.
The contemporary portrait is so vivid.
One can feel the wind in those rustic brushstrokes.

The new law code grounds Mongolian custom and culture, creating stability that supports both industry and the arts. The capital hosts dialogue among the world's four corners, while artisans trade materials, techniques, and secrets in the marketplace, pushing new boundaries in craft.
Local arts make the people stand out, on and off the battlefield.

Following breakthroughs in navigation, Norman travelers venture farther than ever before, returning with tales of strange lands and wildly different peoples. Citizens grow more aware of their own culture, proud of themselves and curious about others in turns.
New perspectives will open new horizons.

In the castle courtyard, a woman entertains children with stories of a legendary ruler with a magic sword. The young ones listen rapt as the king and his knights battle giants, romance women, and venture to the Otherworld. Scribes increasingly recommend adding these tales to the growing body of Norman literature.
Record "Perceval, the Story of the Grail."
Preserve "Lancelot, the Knight of the Cart."

Officials spread out across the Norman Empire to record the value of every shire and every estate. From these numbers, they estimate taxes owed and levies to be sent in times of war. The survey consolidates Norman authority, but its thorough examination of personal profits proves unpopular.
What is good for the empire is good for the people.
Authority must be exercised to be respected.
On a smooth palm leaf by the salt-scented sea, a scribe etches the history of the Majapahit, her breath bated for the marvels she dares preserve by pen.
It is a history of secret kings, after all.
It is the story of a people.

The towering edifices of the pura quarter strike all visitors with awe and reverence. The gardens fill the air with rich scents, and children stare up at the marvelous statues that watch over the land.
This is a space for citizens to rediscover themselves.

Music drifts from an open doorway into the street beyond. The beat of the kendang guides the ensemble as players build a world for their silent audience…one of gongs and resonance, narrated by the rebab's strings.
Gamelan music should be shared with the world.
These musicians will grace local venues.
As astronomers look to the sky, the world opens up around the Songhai. The ocean calls to explorers and traders alike, but the old ways of the river still dwell in the people's hearts.
The river routes must be recorded.

The tajiro stands in the center of the caravanserai, spinning a legend to the delight of fellow merchants. Visitors share tales of their own lands, an exchange that lasts late into the night. Local listeners return to their beds, their imaginations alight. Do the Songhai adapt to new cultural norms, or remain firm in traditional practices?
The ways of the ancestors shall be cultivated.

The Songhai trade networks draw resources and ideas to the epicenter of the capital. Local artisans labor over exquisite masks, collecting materials from the surrounding regions. A collective of scribes uses foreign dyes to illuminate their manuscripts honoring the Kanta.
The mask makers bring beauty and prosperity to Songhai.
The scribes preserve our might for the ages.

Spain enters the world stage with an eye toward lands beyond her borders. Citizens are excited for the future, anticipating the growth of their empire in both territory and minds. As politicians prepare the infrastructure for expansion at home, explorers ready their cargo to set off into the unknown.
The core empire must be strong.
It is time to expand Spain's borders.

The beauty of the plaza draws many visitors to witness Spain's prosperity. With them come new ideas that influence Spanish artists to create masterpieces. The Casa de Contratación has space for one final painting, and the people see this as the perfect opportunity to celebrate a fresh style.
Celebrate realism with an aristocratic portrait.
Embrace mannerism with a religious portrait.

As Spain's art industry blossoms alongside its growth on the world stage, the theater sees an ocean of new plays, and a quixotic novel captures imaginations. Passionate lovers of the arts practically come to blows on the ideal form of storytelling.
New plays keep the theatre alive, at home and abroad.
The novel's critique of chivalry is profound.

Guards watch in horror as a slice of bread tumbles from a murder hole in the gatehouse ceiling. Shedding crumbs on its descent, the half-eaten chunk lands delicately in the lap of a visiting aristocrat. He recoils, peering up at the lunch-less guard. "No eating on duty!" he shouts. "Our shifts are too long!" the soldier yells back.
Ban guards from eating on duty.
The Good Doctor and the Abbasid Metropolis

Weaving his way through the maze of the intricate circular city, Dr. Rizal is dazzled by practically everything he sees: minarets stand as sentinels above the crowds, markets teem with enticements from all over the world, libraries and academies bustle with the greatest minds of these times.
The library must be the center of knowledge.
The market appears to be the heart of local industry.

From their outrigger, Dr. Rizal's Hawaiian guide shows how they use the sun, the stars, the very movement of the water to chart infinite routes across the sea. It is what will always connect them to home, no matter how far they stray.
Ask how far they have strayed.
The Good Doctor and the Inca

From the Inca, Dr. Rizal learns of social ways that run deeper than economics. His guide explains it this way: “What I lack, you may give. And what you lack, I may give. Thus, a balance is preserved.”
The people are great in their abundance.
The commitment to equality is most admirable.
The Good Doctor and the Mongols

Dr. Rizal watches as a group of horse archers training, firing their bows while at full gallop at leather balls lobbed into the air by a leader. No wonder these warriors are able to conquer lands far and wide.
Study how such a great army is supplied.
The Good Doctor and the Castles of the Normans
A guide shows Dr. Rizal a view of an impressive stone castle, part of it sitting atop a mound. The guide explains that it is a ruling lord's home, as well as a fortress for the soldiers he commands.
Study the workings of the fortress.
People should worship as they like.

Adherents of {1_religion} spread its message with the hunger of a devouring fire. But is it the cleansing flame of purification, or the inferno of persecution? Division stirs about the form faith should take – what do the followers of {2_religion} say about those who do not believe?

At the palace vaults, treasurers discuss the secrets to increasing wealth. The head financier asserts that hard work and long hours are the only true method to success, but a junior disagrees: "Happy people will be more fruitful," she argues.

Not everyone believed that a happier work culture could so easily lead to greater wealth, but it seems to be true. Efforts to show appreciation for the workers' labor have clearly led to a flourishing economy.
Hard work truly does pay off, it seems. Though the hours have been long and the workers have complained, the boost in the bottom line is inarguable.
The Good Doctor and the Expanding World
It seems to Dr. Rizal that the world has suddenly grown, offering up new places to visit and new peoples from whom to learn.
The Good Doctor and the Expanding World
It seems to Dr. Rizal that the world has suddenly grown, offering up new places to visit and new peoples from whom to learn.
The Good Doctor and the Strange Familiar World
While regaling his fellows with tales of his travels upon returning home, Dr. Rizal is struck by a peculiar thought. “The world has expanded so, and yet it seems… smaller, does it not?”
Meet all Civilizations in Distant Lands.
Meet all Civilizations in Distant Lands.

As the sun rises over Chola society, new opportunities open up for skills and professions. The merchant guilds of the nagaram are eager to set sail and expand their trade routes – and through these, Chola influence. But the local artisans who craft, weave, and smith the necessary wares caution that it is better to perfect their products first.
Mastery takes time, but pays immense dividends.

Chola merchants spread across the world under the auspices of the Five Hundred Lords. Beneath the flag of the bull, they manage the finest wares and rake in profits to match, prompting discussion from many merchants on how to reinvest into society.

Chola ships ride the monsoon winds across the oceans, but they are not as united as they once were. Many smaller factions have grown up to become powerhouses of their own, sowing division despite their great contributions.
Hawai'i grows, and with it the prosperity of its people. The careful cultivation of mana encourages both individuals and communities to reach higher than ever in their aspirations for greatness.
Take in new ideas from abroad.

Recent taro crops in the lo'i kalo have produced great bounties. Many thank the efforts of the kahuna and his close observation of kapu to enrich the land. But farmers worry that their good harvests will not last, and wish to engage more directly in their own journeys toward enhanced mana.
The harvest is a time for celebration.

Hawaiians gather on the beach to watch the surfers ride in on immense swells. Admiring the power of the ocean, one remarks that only by becoming one with the sea can greatness be achieved. His companion gently probes whether such traditional beliefs can last in the face of modernity.
The old ways are steadfast as the sea.
Progress is as certain as the tides.

Architects gather to plan the construction of defenses, and find themselves with more lumber than expected. They debate whether this surplus should be used for the construction of additional walls or if they should preemptively strengthen existing bastions with wooden hoarding in case of war.

A fisherman finds a merchant ship wrecked against a reef, and begins gathering the goods among the flotsam. The vessel's owners unexpectedly return, sparking an argument. Is the ship in public waters, or too close to the beach to count as a wreck?
The find goes to the fisherman.
The cargo should be returned to the merchants.

A letter arrives from a bishop, requesting a reduction in the amount of soldiers he must contribute to the army. He insists the quota is too high for his community...but perhaps he can offer something else in their stead.

The captain of the palace guard requests additional soldiers to expand the ranks. He wishes to hire foreign mercenaries, saying they will always be loyal so long as they are paid. Several aristocrats shake their heads, declaring that a position in the guard would bring greater honor to local troops.
Norman soldiers are the world's elite.

A scribe working on the Domesday Book discovers that he has mixed up two Roman numerals and some of his numbers are wrong. He looks around to see if anyone can review his recent work for mistakes.[N][N]Then again, if he says nothing...who will notice?

Complaints have been raised over the raucous culture surrounding pigeon racing. The constant swarms of birds above Abbasid cities are accompanied by the shouts of trainers, fans, and gamblers making wagers on the racers’ success.
Much joy can be found in the sport's social nature.

Two architects present a plan for a round city, a rare construction to celebrate Abbasid greatness. Other architects scratch their heads, wondering how standard rectangular houses will conform to the curved walls.
Beauty is more important than space.

Two alchemists argue over how to transmute metals into gold. One lectures on the careful combination of the four elements – air, earth, fire, and water. The other shakes his head, confident that the answer lies in the mixture of sulphur and mercury.
Strange appetites often surface amid the chaos of war. Soldiers gather over a plate of cooked pufferfish, each carefully choosing a slice that might kill with its poison.
The thrill of death sweetens the meal.

The sea's bounty fills plates across the empire, and items crafted of whalebone and decorated with pearl proliferate in market stalls. The oceans provide, yet they also have many lessons to teach to those who watch and listen.
Divers find new reefs along the ocean's edge. Within them dwell newly discovered species of underwater fauna. What more could be hiding in these underwater kingdoms?

Scholars toss pieces of driftwood into the sea along the coastline and watch for their return. As the wood reappears – or vanishes – these observers determine new systems of currents that will help travelers navigate the blue abyss.
As war rages in the streets, a couple flees into the hills, burying a family heirloom along the way. They hope they might someday return for it when the conflict is ended.
Caches of valuables will facilitate rebuilding once the conflict is over.
The end of the war brings many citizens back to their abandoned homes. Amid the crowds, a couple digs upon a hilltop until they find the token of love they buried at the war's beginning.

A girl on her way to market stubs her toe against a surprisingly hard object buried in the dirt. Brushing away the soil, she unearths a wondrous golden horn decorated with depictions of ancient life, remarkably well-preserved for how ancient it seems.
Display the horn for all to admire.
Commission drinking vessels based on its design.

A farmer plowing his field finds another intricate golden horn, made of the same craftsmanship as the one unearthed near the market. The pair of reunited treasures are celebrated as representations of ancient ingenuity.
Join the horns at an exhibit to honor history.
Commission research into their ancient legacy.
As a community, authors and visual artists band together under one inspiring imperative: to expand the mind, freeing each individual from dated social constraints.
Deconstruct the old ways through art.
Hold to tradition in creative practice.
The arquebusiers perish far from home, yet their loved ones still wait eagerly for their return.
Bring them home at all costs.

Families await news of their seagoing relatives, but nothing has been heard for months. The pain of their loved ones' uncertain fate hangs heavy above their heads, yet to know for certain they will never return would be an agony all its own.
Perform an exhaustive search for a wreck.
Declare the heroism of those forever lost.
The clash of weapons and sound of gunfire ring in the air as the vanguard charges, falters, and falls. Their sacrifice underlines the high cost of their cause.
Observers on the beach gasp with horror as they watch the carrack go down with all hands. The wreckage soon washes ashore, and the beach fills with mourners and opportunists alike.
Hold a memorial for the lost.
A group of ambitious women have set out to design an embroidery depicting the history of the Normans. They present each other with samples of their work, representing many different styles.
The recent victory of the Norman army has inspired the imaginations of embroiderers across the land. They gather to create a work that captures the action and violence of conquest.
Sponsor a single textile of the full narrative.
Commission wall hangings of crucial scenes.

Two peasants argue over the source of Songhai might. One praises the might of the army and their talent for bloodshed. The other scoffs. “You’ve never even touched a sword – but you help those merchants all the time. Aren’t they the backbone of imperial might?”
The warriors' might powers the empire.
Songhai is built upon trade routes.

A truffle hunter runs through a rural village, claiming to have seen fairies in the woods. He shouts that they will bring good fortune to the people if they are left in peace. Some whisper he ought to be more careful eating mushrooms.

A diplomatic meeting is arranged in the tropics to strengthen the recent alliance. As the congress breaks for lunch, a diplomat stops at an open air restaurant to grab a bite to eat.[N][N]As he lifts a slice of bread to his mouth, a monkey swings down and grabs it out of his hand!
Welcome the diplomat to the tropics.

A monk asks his abbot: how many krakens live in the seas? Although the abbot chides his charge for believing in children's tales, the monk secretly knows better. There must be only two, else all living things in the seas would be eaten!
The kraken is only a legend.
The court must study kraken behavior.

A watchmaker visiting from afar shows off their latest commission for their patron: a pendant watch adorned with red gems and an ivory cameo. Inside, tiny and intricate moving parts conspire to tell the correct time within half an hour!
With a war in full swing, the Holy City isn’t safe for anyone, not even the soldiers. The pilgrims cannot be deterred from their mission of worship, and still they come.
The pilgrims are the brave ones.
This will only burden the soldiers.

A priest tenderly carries a tiny spider outside to the garden, and sets it free. The people have embraced ahimsa: non-violence, never declaring war in anger. One should not kill nor cause another to kill.
"All tremble at violence; all fear death. One should not kill nor cause another to kill." - Siddhartha Gautama, the Buddha
The Good Doctor and the Copper Plates

Dr. Rizal watches as detailed inscriptions are hammered into a copper plate, one of the many royal charters that formed the basis of Chola recordkeeping. This one appears to grant exclusive rights to certain trade routes. Another nearby, just finished, defines the boundaries of certain lands.
The Good Doctor Meets the Majapahit

Engrossed in the humming capital of the Majapahit Empire, Dr. Rizal feels a certain kinship with the faces so similar to his own. Haggling with a particularly eager merchant over a bauble, he even finds that certain words come easily to him.
In the bustle of the crowded port, an enormous docked galleon stops Dr. Rizal in his tracks, taking his breath away. The ideas it conjures are almost overwhelming.
The places it must have seen...
...the suffering it is sure to have brought.
The Good Doctor and the Caravanserais of the Songhai
Following the trade routes in the company of a griot, Dr. Rizal finds the caravanserai a welcome sight. Though soldiers are everywhere, their only concern seems to be that the goods go undisturbed.
Learn of the goods that pass through here.
Observe the soldiers as they train.
The people are descended from the gods, and will become gods once more. Though others may deal violence, they rise again greater than before, in the shadow of Mount Meru.
Cling to life and the struggle.
Embrace the fall, and the glories that come after.
When gaining rewards from a Narrative Event, gain an additional 30 [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture.
The gamelan plays, a new instrument added to the polyphony even as soldiers fall, each body a hammer upon the brass gong.
The hero falls, his golden helmet making an arc like a falling star.

Those cut down by the enemy lay dead in rows. Each fall is as graceful as a dancer's. Each dying breath carries the fragrance of frangipani. The scarlet that runs in the streets is more lustrous than the finest dyes. They are finished, and in completion, they are beautiful.

Clad in simple black robes, the new order dedicated to spreading the beliefs of the {1_civilization_adj} people moves in lands far from home. Their claims to poverty increase their appeal; their proximity to foreign luxuries increases their influence.
The divine and secular worlds are aligned.
The people have longstanding traditions and philosophies against despotism, and it will not be in their nature to accept a king. Advisors say it is urgent to find some way of reassuring them.
Place the crown on a ceremonial statue.
Repurpose traditional symbols of Roman governance.
The observatory marks a striking comet, perhaps the same ancient one returned once more. It hangs in the sky like a statement.

The sekti segara, the might of the sea, strikes again. Like the onset of an ocean storm comes its commander, collapsing enemy resistance as suddenly as a crashing wave. He is as omnipresent as the shark's dark shadow, as unstoppable as the leviathan.

The top of the mountain is shrouded in smoke, and fire pours down its sides. The villagers say that long ago, a queen threw her only son into the crater, and each time it erupts it brings not only fire, but prosperity and peace.

Travelers gather around a glowing fire in the dark, watching a poisonous spider casting long, eerie shadows in the dark. What, one asks, does such a lethal creature contribute to the natural order of things?
All creatures are expressions of the divine.
What is dangerous to one is beneficial to another.

A scholar has completed an insightful new Book of Animals, a massive exploration of the natural world. This opus looks at animal evolution and the ecosystem in complex ways that are often hard to distill to a single message.
The environment has influenced animal evolution.
The natural world is a large web.
From sunrise to sunset, scholars engage in the study of the spatial world, creating vivid illustrated maps and having heated debates on the calculations of the world.
Complete the map of its lands.
The Compendious Book on Calculation by Completion and Balancing, penned by a famous scholar, is an imposing, heavy tome. The delivery of the final manuscript stirs up a great cloud of dust.
Make copies available in the library.
A soft breeze stirs the trees as Ibn Sīnā reclines on a balcony. He is thinking of the nature of existence and essence. Can existence itself be proven by the essence of a thing that already exists?
The nature of things is an endless mystery.
This moment on a fine day is all that exists.
A patient requests Ibn Sīnā's attention for a rare condition, hunched over in pain she claims came out of nowhere. The doctor wonders whether diseases can manifest from nothing.
The symptoms matter more than the source.
A crowd surrounds Al-Maqdisi as he relates tales from his latest voyage. Already he longs to return to the road, but it would be valuable to record his adventures while they are fresh in his mind.

Al-Maqdisi's geography of the Abbasid world illustrates the compelling diversity of its cultures, people, and beliefs. Travelers are inspired to follow in his footsteps, and locals welcome visitors with curiosity and enthusiasm.

Al-Farghānī gazes up at the night sky, noting the position of the moon compared to last night, and the night before, and the night before that. He suspects previous calculations of its orbital path are incorrect.
It is essential to correct the error.
The moon's mysterious journey has its beauty.

Al-Farghānī's latest work is called A Compendium of the Science of Stars, a careful treatise that makes complex astronomy accessible to all. Now children are as excited to learn about the sky as the navigators.
Send the first copies to schools.
Place a copy on every ship.

As the shahrud's strings resound beneath the musician's fingertips, Al-Farabi closes his eyes and contemplates the melody. Its emotion soothes his soul, yet he also discerns patterns in its notes and rhythm.
A mathematical theory underlies such harmony.

Al-Farabi's philosophical works argue that true happiness comes from perfection, itself attained through rigorous intellectual pursuit. Some say that is only a means of glorifying the scholarly life, but those who dream find new meaning in their adventurous imaginings.
The dream of better things builds new worlds.

Many are in awe of the asceticism displayed by Rabia of Basra. She renounces the world and devotes her every moment to praising and honoring the divine. She inspires many to try to join her in seclusion, though such a life is far harder than she makes it look.
The population is abuzz with new teachings from Rabia of Basra: loving the divine for its own sake, rather than in the hopes of a reward. Some will surely reconsider the tenor of their prayers.

As Abbasid power grows, the people worry about rival powers and enemies within and without. As a means of managing their fear, philosophers and scholars frequently discuss the reasons for warfare, and which among them is the most just.
The people's safety comes before all.
Many young people are passionately intolerant of non-believers living within Abbasid borders, but one wise disciple presents a series of laws by which these differences may coexist peacefully.

Children and adults alike gaze in wonder at a marvelous creation crafted by Al-Jazari, where a small human automaton travels across a large elephant with a tower on its back. This unique animation is possible thanks to a bowl of water filling in the elephant's belly, and as the human figure strikes its little drum, the time of day is told.
Such clocks are sure to become a trend.
Timepieces need only to be practical.

Worshippers arriving for prayers at the mosque are greeted by a new creation: a peacock statue that spills water from its beak into their hand-washing basin, until a small automated man pops out of the peacock to offer towels.
This fountain should be in daily use!
This marvel should be kept for special occasions.

Wrapping his cloak tighter around himself, Ibn Fadlan watches the landscape around him change from familiar to unfamiliar. The plants, animals, and people look strange…but a shiver of excitement runs down his spine. There is so much to learn, and so many stories await.
He will gain much from observing the people.
The landscape conceals many lessons in its beauty.

The farther Ibn Fadlan travels from home, the more he becomes entranced with the novelties he sees. Yet he cannot help but compare them against his homeland. On the one hand, the habits and dress of the locals are fascinating. On the other hand, the giant snake skeleton shown to him by guides is haunting his nightmares.
Commentary is sometimes more productive than objectivity.
One should not believe everything one sees.

Ibn Fadlan watches closely as an aging priestess calls out to unknown gods from the deck of a deceased lord's ship. He cannot understand her language, but finds himself captivated as she draws a knife to begin the sacrifice. What did this lord do in life to deserve such a burial?
Such traditions must be recorded and preserved.
The old ways stir difficult emotions.

A furor erupts over religious icons, as a few prominent religious voices declare them sacrilegious images. Production begins to halt, and existing icons are being snatched and destroyed all over the city.
Artisans produce more religious icons than the temple has room to store. Priests suggest they might be sold to pilgrims, but some say the icons should never leave the temple grounds.

A group of missionaries forms a rogue order that follows an extreme branch of meditation. They claim that standing on their heads for hours at a time brings them closer to enlightenment, but passersby worry for their health – and sanity.

A monastery requests permission to form a new order, but the monks disagree on their core mission. Some claim charity will make the biggest impact in their local community, while others argue that an ascetic lifestyle will lead to breakthroughs in the divine nature of being.
Funds should be allocated based on charitable works.
The monks' asceticism does them good.

A group of knights seems to be forming their own religious order, bringing faith and strength into harmony. This devotion is welcomed by their commander, but missionaries question the role of violence in piety.
Temper the flames of knightly faith.
The path of faith is littered with books and scholarly studies, but many believe that travel abroad for missionary work will widen spiritual vision even more.
The path of faith is littered with books and scholarly studies, but many believe that travel abroad for missionary work will widen their spiritual vision even more.
The victorious soldiers raise their weapons as the enemy falls before them. They raise their voices too, uttering prayers in gratitude for the divine gift of strength to protect their people.
The descent of war upon the land has disrupted supply lines. Merchants scramble to import enough food to meet the people's needs, but prices climb ever higher, and so does anxiety.
The Good Doctor and the Ming
While traveling with the Ming, Dr Rizal is shown a vase of stunning blue and white porcelain, a classic emblem of Ming artistry and ingenuity.
Study the techniques of its craft.
Wealth flows through the land like a river, offering up priceless nourishment: economic security.
Strength is best measured by the skill of its use. Wisdom sharpens power's blade.
Duty to one another is duty to the self. Diplomacy grows more powerful with practice.
Over the horizon, there is always another horizon. Reach grows like the dawn.
The people look at one another and ask: who are we? Their cultural heritage deepens.
Progress marches on, driven by discovery. The people's thirst to know the workings of the world cannot be quenched.

Disgruntled merchants share water and bemoan their aching feet as they rest from the road – the guildhall seems to grow farther and farther away the bigger the settlement expands! If only there were a guildhall in every city, to save the travel. Then again, that would also mean a guild in every city, with all their hierarchies and power struggles attending.
The guildhall is a jewel for the capital.

A disillusioned scholar wanders among the enthusiastic merchants' stalls, perusing some wares before lazily picking up a chipped beaker. "Have the Ming fallen behind on progress?" He sighs loudly, and puts it back.
Trade is essential to the economy.
Science is more important than coin.

The xunleichong humbles all who wield it. The soldiers find it cumbersome at first, laughing nervously at the power in its weight. But in time they grow in their handling, until the machinery is practically a seamless extension of the body.
Train only elites for this unit.

Ming was powerful before the Great Wall rose, but no representation could convey their true authority. Now, a wondrous construction stands, drawn of mountain stone and the dirt of the earth, a demonstration of the power to draw beauty from nothing.

In a tight-knit village community, small children reach underneath the chickens once again in the hopes of more eggs, while their mothers share dwindling supplies of rice down to the grain. There is not enough food to go around.
Eligible youth should go abroad in search of work.
The local economy must be developed.
A class of scholarly bureaucrats anxiously await the results of their civil service exams. The dread is palpable – after all, they studied long and hard in order to one day serve their government.
Assign the top talent to economics.
Direct the best graduates toward science.

The envoys of Machiavelli are the subject of much admiration: their advice is always sensible, and their focus is always the best interest of the other party. Refreshing indeed to negotiate with such fair-minded people!

A closed border denies the Ming so much, from new cultures and their foods to significant trade opportunities. Isolation leads to stagnation and many wonder whether it's time to open the gates to outsiders.

Ming has opened its borders to surrounding neighbors, with residents equal parts anxious and curious over the new policy. There are new teas to try, and books to study, and thoughts to exchange among brilliant minds.
Start a Trade Route with 2 Civilizations.

A group of disgruntled eunuchs rally and approach the emperor, demanding better working conditions. As a marginalized group stripped of their past selves, they have no power, repurposed only to serve.
Put down their rebellion by any means.
The tension between expansion and tradition is as old as time. Yet it lights up the hearth with passionate arguments among families just as surely as a fire freshly struck.
Swift growth is good, even if it comes with pains.
People cannot be forced to change before they're ready.
Every One in Their Right Place
Prosperity ensues once every member of our empire knows and fulfills their role.
Emphasize Ren, that all may understand their value to one another.
Emphasize Yi – every person has a duty, and a need to fulfill it.
Emphasize Li, so proper customs are observed.
A warrior rises from the battlefield, his shark-toothed club shattered, but his face triumphant.
On the far shores, a spark of knowledge is struck. But only the breath of wisdom can make it spread like fire.
In distant lands, the light of learning expands, drawing its residents closer to understanding...and to Trung Trac's diplomatic goals.
Build a University in Distant Lands.

In the lower district, a peasant's hovel stands studded with arrows and the scorch-marks of fire. At the entrance is a pile of enemy dead, and inside rests the body of the farmer's son. He alone stood against the tide.
The desire for freedom can be stronger than life.
As the true religion extends outward, those in the Majapahit interior still cling to the Kapitayan, the old ways. The priests in their temples consider this...
A cultural feature of the heartland.
Majapahit cities grow close and dense, as rural migrants crowd with generations-old city-dwellers. The new migrants bring much of value, however.
With a blast, the Mongol ship disappears beneath the waves. As the white water foams, a cheer rises from the Majapahit decks.
The Majapahit merchants are the masters of taste – they know precisely what their clients want, from the furs of the frozen north to the fiery spices of the equator.
The bazaar is a place of wonders.
The Majapahit are the people of the sea. Its salt is in their veins, its tides their hearts.
Harmony, order and tradition are pillars of Ming society. But scientific enquiry often stands to upend these very ideals, especially when progress happens too quickly.

All parents want their children to grow up virtuous and wise, but there is much disagreement on the best way to raise them. Some say children learn best through practical experience, while others insist rigorous study is the only way to prepare for the real world. If the destination is the same, does the path truly matter?
There is no substitute for practical experience.

A city gone, but not forgotten. While the Ming grieve their loss, they do not take for granted the journey they took thanks to their ambition. Displaced residents band together, determined to find fertile ground and make something new from nothing.
Do not give up on Wonders.
Time to invest in other things.
Any farmer or miner has the opportunity to take up scholarly work, though the study is hard. Why so few choose to pursue this path is its own question.
There are no limits to Amina's ambition. Even the horizon is no boundary – merely a challenge.
With iron and steel, all will be hers.
The land will turn gold before her.
A group of hunters pause as the grass sea is shaken to its stalks. Does the earth quake? No, it is the drumming hooves of Amina's army, and jackals gathering in anticipation of the dead.
Each blade of grass trembles before their general.
Wood collapses beneath furious fires as battle rages in the streets. But the chaos of war will soon be replaced by a new order as Amina's rule advances across the earth.
It is a mere show of intimidation.
Amina's soldiers unwrap bundles of dates for their lunch, leaving trails of pits in their wake as they urge their horses on.
Amina's empire grows upon the might of her soldiers. Their tireless service instills confidence in the populace and fear in the hearts of enemies.
For Amina, the land represents only the first stage of her domination. The seas hold both enemies and wealth, for those who dare to master them.
The winds rise. Now is the time to embark.
Amina's people flock to watch the treasure convoy arrive. Such riches, once beyond their imaginations, will now become commonplace.
The ocean currents must be studied first.
Amina's name is synonymous with gold: gold dangles from her ears, gold adorns her belt, and gold runs through her dreams.
Amina has draped her empire in gold, and her people gleam like stars in the night.
Ashoka watches his people pray. Some ask for power, others for wisdom. As for Ashoka, he knows there are many ways to rule the world...depending on how one views it.
The world exists to be mastered.
A ruler finds guidance through humility.
Ashoka has made the palace a holy site. But the monks grow restless, wondering if their role as the keepers of knowledge is threatened by their leader.
A bodhisattva rises above ecclesiastical politics.
The people look to the divine to understand their place in the world. But the root of their trust lies in Ashoka.
Ashoka lowers his head below the monks', like any lay person.

Mount Meru is the abode of the gods, a shining peak surrounded by a heavenly sea. And Ashoka's capital is built in its image, encrusted with gold and the fine things of the world. The symbolism could not be more plain.
The riches of the world, the riches of the divine – both can be found within Ashoka's aura.
Gather Cocoa, Sugar, Tea, and Spices.

Two monks grow famous throughout Ashoka's land. One teaches a practice of quiet self-reflection, that through introspection and self-knowledge one can gain unity with the universe. The other, oddly enough, is a materialist, stressing an engagement with the world.
To know the world, one must know oneself.
The university is a quiet place, a haven for silent study and meditation that enriches Ashoka's empire.
The Call of the Temple Bell
Before the dawn, chants spill from the temples through the streets, carrying with them the scent of devotees' incense. All are called to community, and at the same time, to self-knowledge.
The Call of the Temple Bell
The scent of incense drifts on the breeze through Ashoka's settlements. All pause in their daily work, inhaling its fragrance together as one.
Visions of power pass through Augustus' mind. A great city of marvels transforms into an immense army, banners waving in the wind. One of these will be made reality.
Beneath Augustus' rule, order may be cloaked in a priest's robe or an artisan's tunic. What matters is that services are provided, and taxes – and respect – are delivered in full.
Augustus sits atop a tower of temples.
The temple fills with worshippers, eager to show their devotion to the divine and its earthly vessel. Their prayers are no surprise to Augustus, and he accepts them without hesitation.
Only through art can the world be understood.
In every city square, a marble of Augustus stands. His youthful, serious face stares out at every citizen, eternally seeking their gaze.
From Augustus' determined marble eyes spreads a vision of a grand empire – one that even crosses the seas.
Have your Founded Religion in Distant Lands.
Augustus's soldiers have begun displaying more loyalty to their commanders than to their realm. A worrying trend, perhaps, for feudal loyalties to rise above admiration of the Caesar himself.
Each shield shall bear Augustus' likeness.
By foot, by steed, by bolt – the art of war sees these elements combined. Under the command of Augustus, their very shields mark them as a single army, united by the image of their leader.
Train a Knight, Man-At-Arms, and Crossbowman.
All have their own reasons to fight. Loyalty is all that matters.
Red is the color of the military, purple the color of royalty. All understand their roles at a glance, their eyes comprehending even before the distinction of thought.
The order of power, extending down from Augustus, spreads far and wide.
Capture a Settlement in Distant Lands.

Ben Franklin ponders a new chart of the oceans. Something strange is occurring – certain ships seem to move faster than others, even those expected to arrive at the same time. Tapping his pen against his inkwell, Franklin ponders this mystery and what it might mean for his own people.
The impact of the ocean's currents must be deciphered.
Mapping these currents will benefit all.
Local sporting matches frequently end in brawls among fans dissatisfied with the outcomes. Franklin considers solutions from his advisors.
The popular lectures sponsored by Franklin have grown far beyond their humble origins. Students travel from all provinces to hear the teachings of the world's most eminent scholars.
Channel this aggression into the military.
In the inns and coffee houses, once the day's fare is done, tables are cleared away for scholars to give lectures – their audience is whoever will come, and the admission is a penny.
The baker, the miller, the tailor – all have something to say about the latest advances in science and philosophy.
Have 3 Urban Districts with 30 total yield.
Ben Franklin listens closely to recent reports from distant shores. Many opportunities await – new friends, and great riches. The only question is where to begin.
Word spreads quickly across the seas: Ben Franklin's ear is open to reason. His new allies celebrate their mutual success, and toast to future projects.
Become Suzerain of an Independent Power in Distant Lands.

Laughter echoes out of the hall, resounding in the corridor even before Franklin reaches the room. Inside, a delegation from foreign lands seems especially eager to talk politics – and wine, of which they've giddily imbibed already.
The cost of the diplomats' wine was worth it – an alliance has been forged out of friendship and mutual respect. Franklin signs the document with gusto.
Have an Alliance with another Civilization.
The starry night sky reflects the pinpoints of light stretching across Catherine's empire. They tell the story of the universe, and the legends of those humans bound by earth.
New scientific studies must be commissioned.
The tales behind the constellations must be retold.
A controversial intellectual seeks Catherine's patronage. He argues that the widespread education of the public will greatly advance society, and place increasing power in the hands of the masses.
Disagree. Education is fine for some, but surely there must be some standards.
Power and knowledge, art and beauty, are better refined in the classroom.
The hard winter finds the hunter wandering free in the taiga, dog at his heels. His cabin is adorned with frozen pelts, which will line the coats of soldiers and the fur of Catherine's capes alike.
The comfort of warm furs imbues Catherine's officers with not only warmth, but authority. As their knowledge guides the army, so too their image inspires even the lowliest soldier.

"The light of truth may shine from the humblest candle, as bright as a golden brazier, for it is truth," say the priests. They wander the most impoverished regions, ministering to the everyday lives across Catherine's realm.
Faith makes the lives of peasants better.
Beyond Catherine's borders, the light of truth spreads to communities eager to engage with the holy community of her adherents.
Convert a Settlement that isn't yours.
Inspired workers will make crafts for the tsarina.

Catherine gazes at the gold-encrusted icons of the saints inside the temple's inner sanctum. Their softly glowing radiance forms a halo for the holy man, his back stooped with age as a reminder of human frailty in contrast to the light of the divine.
The riches of Catherine's temples now adorn a greater edifice. Though man be mortal, such a wonder grants fame – and through fame, immortality.
News spreads quickly through Charlemagne's empire: on the far side of the world, cities await, dotting the land like stars in the sky.
Like stars, they must be studied.
Charlemagne stands like a beacon on the hilltop, his sword gleaming in the sun. The victorious warrior bows low before him, and graciously the king touches his shoulders with the deadly blade.
This victory is only the beginning.
Banners wave in the wind, signaling the end of the siege. Charlemagne rides through the gates and the army parts to reveal the true hero of the battle: a soldier whom the king once knighted.
This soldier shall serve at Charlemagne's side.
War is not limited by land, but the waves are difficult to conquer. They are treacherous, swallowing Charlemagne's vessels and dragging them down to the briny depths.

Charlemagne peers through his spyglass. Cannon fire echoes in the distance as his ships cough out puffs of smoke. Suddenly a loud crack – and the enemy vessel breaks apart upon the waves. The king smiles grimly.
Savage kings declare their right to be held by conquest, but wise ones know that a feast wins more hearts than a pike.
Diplomats come and go from Charlemagne's palace. They know that in his presence, their voices have value – and they know his advice is worth more than gold.
Become Suzerain over an Independent Power in Distant Lands.
Charlemagne has learned how to procure excellent mutton.

Charlemagne bends over his ledger. Frowning, he strikes boar from the feast plans for the visiting emir. He has learned that much. But there will be golden plates, and brass trumpets. And, perhaps, a fool.
The magnificence of Charlemagne's feasts are legendary, not only for the finery of the food, but the beauty of the surroundings.
Have 3 Districts that are not the City Center with 40 total Yield each.
There are many ways to rule an empire. Yet Confucius is determined to guide his followers to the moral truth, so that they may transform the world around them for the betterment of all.
It is time for these ideas to spread.
The populace must work hard to understand these concepts.

Confucius knows that his people are loyal. They would follow him across the ocean, even upon the crudest raft. But loyalty alone is not goodness – without discernment, how can one tell right from wrong?
The people will learn by doing.
The followers of Confucius enact his teachings in all their settlements. Though they wander far from his capital, they become more staunch in their adherence to his lessons.
Wants and needs inspire many rulings on the global stage. For Confucius, all decisions depend upon one question: is this moral or immoral?
Harmony within feeds harmony without. In the same way, the unity of Confucius' people determines cooperation abroad.
Have an Alliance with another Civilization.
Priests instruct Confucius' people on the divine order of the universe. They implore the crowds to not only learn this heavenly structure, but to practice its lessons in their daily lives.
In all temples, Confucius' priests guide their followers in rites that both honor the heavens and celebrate the reflection of divine moral order on earth.
The divine can be invoked through less formal means.
Confucius inspires the people's minds, and they translate this inspiration into the physical world. All marvel at their architectural genius.
The cities of Confucius are wondrous to look at. But even more than a feast for the eyes, they are machines for learning, production, and innovation.
Have 4 Districts that are not the City Center with 40 total Yield each.
A Song for a New Era
Within Friedrich's borders, the clash of weapons harmonizes with the sweet strains of the concerto. And beyond?
A Song for a New Era
The music of war will resound across land and sea.
A Song for a New Era
New melodies await beyond the horizon.

Friedrich knows that, just as with a grand play, a direct assault might inspire the hearts of citizens back home. But a canny strategist could cut supply lines and demoralize the front lines, making war unbearable without so much as a shot fired.
Friedrich's army marches through the gates. Their conquest was bold – and through that boldness, successful. Now all that remains is to reap the benefits of victory.
War is a drama, a narrative.
Friedrich detests coffee, but too much wine is not good for morning wars.
Grimacing at the lingering taste of coffee, Friedrich is forced to acknowledge that his army was energetic in their dawn conquest. He is even in the mood for negotiations with his defeated foe.
The ancients dreamed of a philosopher king. But in this era – Friedrich's era – a poet king reigns.
Power from wisdom, wisdom from education.
Beauty and knowledge unite at the heart of Friedrich's city, manifesting a spectacle for the ages.
This is a ripe market in which to sell books!
In Friedrich's hall, the casks are opened: a riesling for the reception, a sekt for the toast, and a dark pinot noir for afterwards.
As Friedrich well knows, friendships fostered over wine reach far beyond the dinner table.
Have an Alliance with another Civilization.
All around Tubman's lands, people clamor for her attention. Some want peace – others long for war. What shall she deliver?
Sometimes conflict is the only path.

Prophets walk Tubman's land, declaring that the end of days is near. Some preach of holding joy in one's heart until the very last, while others promise the temples will keep the faithful safe from what is surely to come.
The faithful pray and raise their arms.
The temples of Tubman's cities are open at all hours, welcoming those in need and bringing joy to the hearts of the people.
True believers work to improve the land in this life.
In the kitchens, long tables are laden with salting meat. There is much to preserve, as Harriet's emissaries have long to walk.
In cities near and far, Tubman's influence takes root and quickly grows into a flowering tree.
Tubman's soldiers do not surrender. They stop only when their bodies give out, and their hearts never do.
Only the best leadership can harness their fury.

As Tubman's soldiers secure the conquered settlement, one commander stands in the central square, reassuring the townsfolk that their lives are safe. Tubman listens to his words, pleased that her values permeate her army even in times of strife.
The armory walls are made of solid fieldstone, thicker than any castle's. Behind them, Tubman's ammunition stockpiles are full.
Weapons are strength, whether they are used or not. Harriet Tubman knows the power of her arsenal…and so too do all in her path.

Hatshepsut studies the map before her. Much is left undrawn, new lands waiting to be discovered. Yet there is so much still to accomplish at home. She rests her finger on her capital as the people await her command.
The riches beyond the horizon must be claimed.
All will know the power of Hatshepsut.

The dreams of kings are elephants, all thunder and strength. But the dreams of pharaohs are falcons: they soar across the sea of night with a piercing gaze and hungry mind. So Hatshepsut’s ships scour the world for places to make her mark, and wealth to carry back with them.
The quest for prosperity is inextricably linked with the quest for the divine.
Arriving upon a new shore, Hatshepsut's voyagers kneel in the sand. They give thanks for their journey's success, and ready themselves for the path ahead.
Start a Trade Route to a Settlement in Distant Lands.
Her ships bring not only conquerors, but explorers.

The goods of the world converge upon Hatshepsut’s markets: dyes of every color imaginable, spices and sweeteners, and precious metals in fur-lined crates. On each, the solar disk, the mark of she whose grace allows this wealth.
Hatshepsut's markets overflow with the wealth of many nations. Within her realm, the trade routes of the world converge.
Gather Sugar, Cocoa, Tea, and Spices.

With their pharaoh as a model, the high priests begin to establish their own cults of personality. Now, each temple displays a row of statues depicting the lineage of holy people associated with the place – and each has its own reputation for miracles.
Belief binds the people as one.
The high priests of Hatshepsut no longer speak only to locals. Their voices, carried by missionaries, now welcome distant cities to join them in prayer.
Discourage this. Temples are there for tangible benefit, not dubious miracles.

The monument industry is nearly as impressive as the wonders they produce. Numerous expert architects, skilled stonemasons, and paid labor teams are deployed, setting to work with the efficiency of an army – and in the manner of an army, they must be kept supplied.
Deliveries of marble, gold, and horses energize Hatshepsut's builders. Now that they no longer worry for resources, they indulge their imaginations to the fullest.
Have Gold, Horses, and Marble Resources.

Himiko's people watch the vivid sunrise as it slowly colors the city. Rays of rosy light reach across rooftops, banishing shadows from buildings and doubts from hearts. Beneath dawn's beams, the palace glows as brightly as the sky.
The palace burns brightly in the minds of many.
By the sun's grace, the city will prosper.
The rural folk, wrapped in furs and rough cloth, hang the bronze mirror of Amaterasu in their dwellings, knowing that she watches over them in the wild places of the land.
Even the humblest woodcutters know Amaterasu's story.
As Himiko's supremacy expands, more folk feel the gaze of Amaterasu, watching and guiding them through their everyday lives.
Become Suzerain over an Independent Power.
These hunters must spread Amaterasu's message.
