Before the dawn breaks, the hunters descend from the mountain laden with furs: silver tanuki, brown rabbits, and occasionally the gray hide of a mountain wolf. Even the most skilled artisan cannot compete with nature's craft.
Himiko's people, draped in the land's bounty, give thanks to the protection it affords from weather and cold. Beneath her guidance, they are always cared for.
The bronze mirror graces Himiko's temples, reflecting their jade furnishings.
Though Himiko's image is banned, her face can be seen in mirrors.
The bronze mirror spreads across the land. In each temple, the populace rejoices beneath Himiko's gaze.
Pilgrims spread Himiko's grace into the world.
Himiko's temples are furnished with fine flat discs of jade, though no jewel can match her face.
The beauty of jade captivates Himiko's craftspeople. They seek new ways to cut and shape the mineral, and so harness its powers further.
News reaches Ibn Battuta of lands far beyond his own border. But Ibn Battuta does not wish to hear of such things – he prefers to experience them with his own senses.
Such tales can be found at home.
Ibn Battuta delights in crossing the edge of the map. But what will he find there? The land is full of resources – and the sea is covered in treasure-laded ships.
The land will provide for the people.
The new settlement begins to grow. Its people delight in exploring their new surroundings as much as Ibn Battuta himself.
Found a Settlement in Distant Lands.
Ibn Battuta's people gather together to praise the divine. Yet sometimes they wonder if their prayers find their way to the right ears.
All who see the relics of Ibn Battuta celebrate these sacred symbols. They guide the peoples' prayers to the divine, just as Ibn Battuta guides their adventures on earth.
Trade routes are nothing without a beginning and an end. They are lines that stich one golden point on the horizon to another.
Traders and tourists eagerly end their journeys in Ibn Battuta's empire. There are so many sights to behold, and so much inspiration to draw.
At sunset, the faithful and skeptical alike gather, drinking tea and eating dates. The first stars appear over Ibn Battuta's glorious cities, heralding a wondrous night ahead.
Ibn Battuta's cities draw together deep thinkers and brilliant scholars. Through open discourse, they enlighten one another to new perspectives on society.
Isabella listens carefully to reports from beyond her lands: rich cities await her touch, but some will be less willing to give up their treasure.
Carracks cut the waters, bound for far-off shores – there to find adventure, and to spread the banner of Isabella to lands hitherto unseen.
Go forth to spread the love of empire.
Reports from the new town reach Isabella's eager ears. Evidence of her peoples' success accompanies every letter, in the form of small nuggets of gold.
Establish a Settlement in Distant Lands.
Bring new gold to our shores.
Dusk falls on the harbor as ships unload their silvery, flopping cargo upon the docks. Ropes creak, the sea slaps wood, and oyster-vendors call along with the gulls.
The skill of Isabella's fishermen fills not only her markets, but those across the land, as merchants exchange fish for both coin and stories.
A new order of priests is on the rise in Isabella's realm. Knowledge is their holy practice, and their faith lies in discovering the ways of the world.
All who hear Isabella's priests find themselves persuaded by their call – whether by oratory or intimidation.
Convert a City that isn't yours.
War is costly, but victory pays. For Isabella, such risk is worthy when the outcome is clear.
The defeated citizens open their treasury to Isabella. Some wealth must be left for their recovery, but most of the gold will make its way back to her.
Rizal sits before an empty page. Stories and poems swirl in his mind – some grounded in the reality of his realm, others stretching into the marvels of the unknown.
What – and who – lies beyond the horizon?
A priest wades into the surf, carrying a heavy crate that ultimately sinks the landing craft deeper into the water. All peer curiously to see what such crucial cargo contains: books, only books.
The holy scholar is an example to all.
Rizal collects books, of course – but other relics attract his scholarly attention too. His priests deliver both to satisfy his boundless curiosity.
Take the books, but leave the priest.

As much as Rizal draws inspiration from his people, his people also draw inspiration from him. Their creativity is visible in art, architecture, and elaborate festivals that fill the streets with joy.
A masterpiece rises above Rizal's city, the realization of a vision shared by leader and populace.
The Pole Star hangs fixed, while all of the firmament revolves around it. It is not the brightest star in the sky, but Rizal's sailors have eyes for no other.
They must follow the star to new lands.
Explorers have become civilians, and what was once a new land now quickly becomes familiar as Rizal's influence spreads across the ocean.
There is much to be studied in the heavens.
Instead of the smell of dead fish and sour water, Rizal's docks are perfumed with a thousand delightful scents: cinnamon and clove, nutmeg and makrut lime, citrus and pepper.
Rizal's merchants deliver an endless supply of marvelous goods from across the sea. They are a feast for the senses, and for the imagination.
Gather Cocoa, Sugar, Tea, and Spices.

The candlelight flickers as Lafayette peers closely at a map of the known world. Suddenly he feels a tug, and the parchment gently slides out of his hands, only to be replaced by a newer, larger map. "We have crossed the horizon," the naval captain announces, showing Lafayette new lands to be explored.
The homeland must first be secured.
The artisans of the capital, freed of a sense of obligation to despotic lords, become Lafayette's champions. Increasingly they propose new ways to be involved in civic life.
Hold regular meetings to discuss their proposals.
Lafayette's artisans have advised him well on the importance of art within his realm. Relics old and new astonish viewers with their exquisite and spiritual forms.
Lafayette walks the harbor, inhaling the briny air and the soundscape of bustling docks and fishmongers' calls. Here, he reflects, is the chaos of humanity in all its splendor.

The shipyards never sleep, filled at all hours with the din of carpentry and the smell of sawdust. Their vessels usher Lafayette's people into the wider world and welcome visitors of all backgrounds to see the empire they have built.
Lafayette's astronomers claim the sun is not, in fact, a divine countenance, but a ball of gas that burns far, far away. Nor is the moon a goddess, but a stone floating in the void.
New friends bring new ideas. Lafayette's newest alliance sparks an exchange of knowledge that enriches both peoples.
Have an Alliance with another Civilization.
The people will believe in science, not magic.
Lafayette taps out the ash from his pipe. The winter is cold in the army encampment, but the soldiers at least have the comforts of home: bread, cheese, fish, and tobacco.
A soldier's life is never easy, but Lafayette makes sure his armies are well-provisioned and led by the most experienced generals.

Machiavelli watches the morning sun peer over the horizon. In its brightness, he sees himself, climbing the heavens to its zenith. Sometimes this journey is best made behind the clouds, its mission concealed until true authority is attained. But wealth can be a powerful negotiator.
The hidden path is the surest.
It is possible to be subtle in the open.

A scholar presents himself before Machiavelli, dressed in the latest silks and velvets, orating in detail about the languages and customs of neighboring lands. After him comes another, who looks down at the floor and mumbles about learning from the merchants who visit the home markets.
The riches of the first scholar are appealing.
Machiavelli's scholar was right – neighboring lands are indeed lavish in customs and wealth, and now they deal exclusively with us.
Become a Suzerain over an Independent Power.
The second scholar has overheard marvelous insights.
Diplomacy treads a fine line, as Machiavelli well knows. Eloquent words often do the trick, but sometimes a knife is necessary.
Machiavelli is a master of words and knives. Yet occasionally the most effective diplomacy occurs at the business end of an arquebus.
Start 2 Diplomatic Endeavors and 2 Diplomatic Sanctions.
Machiavelli oversees a generation of indolent youth, clearly with too much energy unburnt. They bicker among themselves and start fights over petty nationalism.
They will learn to conduct themselves abroad.
The rebellious youth of Machiavelli's empire have not found restraint in their travels abroad. They have found something far better: ambition and wealth.
They will be entrusted to the local university.
Wealth is power, and Machiavelli's cities are flooded with riches from across the seas. But there are also riches on the seas…
The treasure convoy's arrival astonishes Machiavelli's citizens and inspires the envy of his enemies. Such is the price of power.
The roads of Pachacuti's empire do not stop at the shore. They extend across the ocean, currents carrying his ships to future provinces and new wealth.
Pachacuti's citizens delight in the rich offerings of local marketplaces. Yet news of more marvelous products soon reach their ears.
All wonder at Pachacuti's merchants, their caravans laden with marvels beyond all imagination.
Artistry is more important than material.
Pachacuti's palace shines golden: a golden mask, a golden seal. When all of the torches are lit, the sun itself has a rival for brilliance.
Even in the lowlands, the people know the warmth of the sun. As their population grows, so too does their reverence for Pachacuti.
Belief spreads rapidly through the populace, although beyond Pachacuti's borders, many are reluctant to hear the sermons of his priests. Their lands will soon be his nonetheless.
They are free to practice what they wish.
Many religions exist under Pachacuti's reign. Though his own belief remains dominant, the joy of the people is more important than any one practice.
Capture a Settlement that does not follow your Founded Religion.
All must follow the same beliefs.
As the settlers embark for new lands, crowds gather to send them off. The expansion of Pachacuti's empire never fails to excite his people.
Neither land nor sea are a match for Pachacuti's ambition. His people spread across the earth and rejoice.

In the skies above Trung Trac's city, the stars tell stories of heroes past and present. Some command interstellar armies raging across the cosmos, while others offer celestial wisdom to those who know where to look.
War in the heavens reflects war on earth.
In knowledge lies the key to success.

The city still smolders even as new workers arrive to rebuild, and debates on what to do next begin before the embers are cooled. Young warriors declare that now is the time to strike back, but humble monks with fervent gleams in their eyes say only divine knowledge can prevent such destruction in the future.
Trung Trac's army rages across the land. All tremble before her might, and the iron and steel of her soldiers.

Attendants cheer as the veil falls away from an enormous portrait. "This is a brilliant likeness of you," an august advisor exults, "a celebration of your generosity, in the leading style!" The smile seems more an uncanny leer, but no one else seems unsettled by it.
Hang this portrait in a place of honor.
Trung Trac never neglects her elephants: there is the one with the wall-breaking tusks, the one with the pearl-white hide, and the one with the gentle eyes.
Inspired by her elephants, the grand galleons of Trung Trac's fleet tower over her ships. And like the elephants, they are both mighty and awe-striking.
Trung Trac's settlements grow like blooms in a field, and so too does the people's sense of community and belonging.
All work together for a common goal.
Trung Trac's cities are never quiet. The clink of hammers and the creak of saws echo in every street as magnificent buildings grow like trees in a forest.
Have 3 Districts that are not the City Center with 40 total Yield each.
All share the same faith in the divine.

Ideas pour into Trung Trac's realm through trade routes, funneling knowledge from all over the world into her markets and beyond. Scholars work together to collect this information and ensure that it benefits everyone.
Between the city and the university flows a plentiful river of ideas. The people of Trung Trac's land are united by innovation, made possible by their collaboration.
Within his own lands, Xerxes reigns with a firm hand, guiding his people to greatness. Beyond his borders, his reputation grows – but where shall he turn his attention?
Now is the time for wealth.
Now is the time for war.
The codes of politeness around Xerxes are legion, but one noble youth knows nothing of them. He speaks directly to the throne, an act so brazen that all the court gasps.
Time in courts abroad will teach decorum.

"O Xerxes," reads a message from a noble youth, "once you sent me from your sight for addressing you directly. As a merchant, I have traveled far and learned the ways of the world. For your mercy, accept these gifts fit only for the eyes of the great Shahanshah."
All are equal in the face of the divine.

The palace chambers are now of plaster painted in deep red, offsetting the royal gold of Xerxes' furnishings. The court is constantly changing with new fashions, and seemingly every month, the architects restyle each room with a new facade.
The efforts of Xerxes' architects, once focused on the palace, have rerouted to grander projects. As always, their taste for opulence does not disappoint.
The flames of Ahura Mazda, the fire god, spread. In their burning is the fate of the world.
Swift fire will cleanse the land!
The armies of Xerxes wash the land of enemies. In their wake, a new world dawns – one fashioned in the image of Ahura Mazda.
The glowing embers burn slow but sure.
Beneath the gaze of Xerxes, the royal flame burns like the sun, leaving only stone unscarred.
The waters of the deep are not enough to quench the flames of Xerxes. If they dare try, he whips them into submission.
Peeling vegetables is hardly pleasant work, but sometimes the servants stand at their task for so long that they go unnoticed – overhearing many juicy details of household scandals.
Rumors are as valuable as currency.
Confucius would want a diplomat to follow the Da Ming Lu when imposing law, would he not? Yet the line between government and faith is often precarious and hard to find.
The law is agnostic to belief.
Laws should express faith within society.
A commander, tall and imposing, inspects the soldiers manning their post. They guard the precious Great Wall, a symbol of Ming power, and will not move even in the most dire of circumstances.
Two diplomats stand over a map, contemplating aloud. Their neighbors are far away, yet nothing has been done to keep up with them.
A heretic is accused of spreading rumors about Himiko's legitimacy. She is a sorcerer, the heretic claims, an evil seductress! How else to explain her air of mysticism?
This heresy must be shut down.
The shrine maiden sweeps leaves from the temple gate, pondering what it means to be spiritual.
Production is nearly complete, and the architect steps back to admire the new building. Soon, it will house a skilled armorer, ready to initiate new recruits with steady hands and confidence.
More arms are needed for the soldiers at once.
The armorer's work is an art that deserves time.
Evidence finds that a trusted agent has been playing both sides, acting as a mole even as they spy for Tubman. "I would never betray you," the accused insists.
Make an example of the mole.
Use the intelligence gained by the mole.
Amina inspects each warrior one at a time, from the calluses on their hands to the sores on their feet. Only the strongest women will be chosen to fight. There is no room for fragility or weakness.
Each warrior carries their own weight.

Though comfort and happiness are hardly requirements for an army, Queen Amina is known to show grace. At the very least, the expanding forces need housing, nourishment and enough armaments to ensure both hands are ready for battle.
Amina’s soldiers, pleased with these new amenities, are ready to show appreciation for the queen’s generosity by way of conquest.
Keep the army as it is.
Amina's insatiable desire to expand her territory leads to certain conflict. All her cities are built on war and trade, but if those routes were to turn hostile, there would be a financial impact.
Restrain the fighters and promote trade.
Some warriors call it a cruelty to deny them the pleasure of fighting. The forces grow restless, never having gone so long without combat.
It is time to strategize and gather strength.
Presented with targets for their blades and land to be pillaged, Amina’s army is all too happy to indulge in warmongering.
Send the warriors to their purpose once more.
With many cities under her reign, Amina considers life after conquest: thousands of new citizens to be brought together under her customs, encouraged to embrace a new way of life.
Involve every citizen in civic work.
Take any measure to ensure contentment.
Tensions between Amina and her neighbors are coming to a head, and neighboring envoy comes bearing an explicit warning: step back, or else. Many believe it was only a matter of time.

For generations, priests have safeguarded a burial shroud once belonging to a great prophet. The people demand the veil be displayed for all to venerate, but the priests believe the relic's safety is key to the land's prosperity.
The dead don't need veils. The people do.
Workers have stopped to gather and stare. Within the recesses of a hollowed-out altar, the team has unearthed a once-forgotten golden relic, a remnant from the origins of {1_religion}.
Construct a reliquary that honors this curio.
Melt the relic into coins to fund construction.
Building a city and nurturing its growth is no easy task – to decide on its future is no easier. Society will bend to whatever comes next.
Culture will grow from folk art and local custom.
Institutions must be built to support arts learning.
Citizens ponder what this means for the city. Perhaps the hand of new policy will be needed to guide society. Perhaps new visitors will come and be awed. Whatever lies ahead, it will be glorious.
Labor and investment alone will grow the arts.
Special buildings should be raised to house arts learning.
From humble origins, this city is destined to become the center of all trade. Appetites from abroad will grow so voracious that merchants will struggle to meet demand.
Ambition must rise to its occasion.
The surplus should be invested in further financial institutions.
A city made of gold, where citizens take their influx of coin and spend it within the community. A trade cycle blossoms, and soon, there will be a robust economic ecosystem behind it.
Focus on the growth of Guilds.
What makes a city feel strong? Streets full of soldiers patrolling proudly, or a vast array of conquered neighbors spreading its influence?
A strong leader sets the example for the rest.
Whether there will be more barracks to support the growing army, or more fleets to bring soldiers home, it is too early to tell.
The soldiers' needs always come first.
Subtle at first, the social fabric will shift toward enlightenment and inquiry. Soon, the city will be transformed into a haven for scientists and scholars alike.
Academic elites will lead this society.
Libraries and academies are under rapid new construction, planned to attract the best and brightest. These centers will give the city a new identity: a hub of technology.
Education is a social value greater than any institution.
The University needs support now more than ever.

A group of scholars have been complaining that the people are forced to live like animals. In protest, they have begun dressing a donkey as a local leader and parading it through the streets, proclaiming it sovereign.
Plan a public feast...of roast donkey.
Challenge the donkey to a political debate.

A physician has documented the "universal malaise" of citizens across town. Thankfully they're also selling an energizing tonic made from naturally carbonated spring water...conveniently sourced from their family's land.
Study the effects of this bubbling water.
Serve this brisk beverage to city workers.

Orphans have been tossing stones from the crown of a crumbling rampart, proclaiming they are now the town's best line of defense. The city used to take pride in the strength of its walls...then that pride collided with the might of the {1_civilization_adj} Empire.
Renew the city's spirits with a festival.
Offer hope by building a monument.

Ferdinand Magellan bows before the Spanish court, as deeply as his war-injured knee will allow. Spain has blessed him with the commission he had sought for so long: to sail the seas and return with untold glory and riches.
Sail farther than any have dared.

Magellan's convoy at last glimpses land. They had been ravaged by storms, plagued by hunger and disease and hardened by mutiny. There is an entire world before them to exploit, but no shortage of local opposition.
Unload a Treasure Convoy worth 3 Treasure Fleet Points.
Leave it up to the wind.

Restless in his comfortable life as an overseer, Francisco Pizarro is compelled by talk of the new world's rumored hoard of riches. He worked hard for all he has, and would work harder still for more.
See what this talk amounts to.
The rumors lead Pizzaro to unimaginable spoils. He claims almost all the gold and silver, angering his lieutenants.
Disperse an Independent Power or Capture a Settlement in Distant Lands.
To the victor go the spoils.

A weary Ponce de León returns from his exploration of nearby lands, frustrated for want of discovery. Still, he cannot stop thinking about the strange ocean current he had encountered, stronger than any wind he'd known.
Tell other ships of this mysterious current.
News of the strong ocean current travels fast, but tales and rumors about a vain search for the fountain of youth compete for Ponce de León's legacy.
Build a Fishing Quay in Distant Lands.
Ponce de León's loss is Spain's profit.
Every lie has a little truth therein.
A brisk stride carries Christopher Columbus as he leaves the Spanish court. Knighthood awaits him on his return, provided his mission succeeds.
This will be an expensive mission.

The newly knighted Christopher Columbus receives the coat of arms, boasting the royal castle and lion. His first journey was a success, but the ripe fields beyond the horizon continue to beckon his thoughts.
Unload a Treasure Convoy worth 2 Treasure Fleet Points.
Hernán Cortés makes for his ship, never once looking over his shoulder to see if the crew will follow. They all know what they must do, and that he will lead them.
Bring Spain's full might to yet-unconquered lands.
Cortés and his men stand among their fallen enemies. He had ordered their ships scuttled, leaving only a path forward.
Defeat an Army Commander in Distant Lands.
Spread Spain's message at all costs.
Hernando de Soto paces restlessly in his lavish mansion, built from his conquests in distant lands. He seeks to return to the throne of command.
De Soto and his men set off to find evidence of a fabled city of gold, but find no such thing. But these lands still bear some fruit, and there is no point in leaving empty-handed.
Have trusted men collect the spoils.

The legend of "El Dorado," a city of riches led by a gilded king, had compelled Francisco de Orellana to adventure. But he returns to Spain nearly broken by his ordeal, describing an immense river untouched by any man.
Disease, starvation and hostile locals threaten Francisco de Orellana and his crew once again. The great river exacts a heavy price, but they have much to gain in return.
Have a Settlement next to a Navigable River in Distant Lands.
+5 Healing in Friendly Territory on Infantry.
Álvar Núñez Cabeza de Vaca boards the ship, ledger securely tucked under his arm. He may only be a treasurer, but a journey like this one would make an adventurer out of anyone.
Fickle fortune leaves Cabeza de Vaca and his few surviving crewmembers stranded and starving. They pose as wandering healers to earn shelter and safe passage through these lands.
Have a Settlement next to a Natural Wonder in Distant Lands.
The Viceroy sends Miguel López de Legazpi on his way. There are lands Spain have not yet claimed, and it falls to Legazpi to correct that mistake.
The locals' resistance proves to be a trifle. Legazpi steps forward as governor of Spain's newest protectorate, but rumors insist that restless pockets of rebellion still stir.
Unload a Treasure Convoy worth 2 Treasure Fleet Points.
{1_reward} worth 2 Points but 2 Tiles are Pillaged in each Distant Lands Settlement.
All will be Spain's in time.
First a mistress and then a nurse, Inés Suárez has lived a life of self-sacrifice. Now granted encomienda rights, she looks to make her own fortune.
Plenty of adventure remains in the new world.
Now an encomendera, Inés Suárez reaps bountiful harvests for herself and for Spain. Still, unrest stirs among the native laborers, who break their backs for the sake of the encomienda.
Have a Fort Town in Distant Lands.
Free Promotion for all Commanders, but 2 Tiles are Pillaged in each Distant Lands Settlement.

In the country shrines, God is seen everywhere in nature, while in the city, practitioners believe God's presence transcends the material. In the temple, philosophical fights break out – a beard or two has been pulled, for certain.
Stop pulling beards. The divine is immanent.
The transcendent divine is far above us, and so is beard-pulling.
Having fought long and well, the crusaders kneel atop the enemy's rampart to be blessed by a priest. After the ceremony, they will turn their attention to what comes next.
There is another pagan outpost to destroy.
The mountain of fire rises high above the plain, a column of smoke and ash rising skyward.
It sends up the people's prayers.
It warns them to leave it be.
A new faith is born, in lands far from home. Young prophets speak of the promise of a society built fresh, with timbers cut from far-flung forests and temples built on distant soil.
The call goes out across the new land.
Like the first drops of the rainy season, like the dawning of the winter's sun, a new world comes into being. The world opens its eyes to a new faith - one faith, one purpose, for all.
The Prime Minister of the Majapahit stares out across the sea. "We will not taste spice until our lands are ours at last," he says.
Found 3 more Settlements. -2 [icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] Happiness in all Settlements while quest is active.
The promised lands of Nusantara have been claimed, and the gods show their favor.

The commander rides into battle clad only in faith, yet enemy fire seems to swerve around him. His friends and foes alike speak in hushed tones about the artifacts he might possess: a fragment of a deva's skull, a demon-haunted dagger?
His fame draws others to the fight.
His prize should be displayed in triumph.
Nothing can take away the camaraderie rooted deep in their bones. A bittersweet goodbye, made endurable by the long-awaited promise of a loved one’s embrace.
A battlefield nourishes the soil with iron. Deep within the layers of earth, life begins anew – remnants of the human cost of war feed into an endless cycle of loss and revival.

Himiko and her handmaidens have not been seen for days, and requests are piling up outside her door. What could she possibly be doing, sequestered away like that? Perhaps it was meant to remain a secret.
Himiko emerges, gesturing to the door. Her handmaidens move with purpose, carrying documents and plans to their intended targets. Whatever transpired behind the scenes is set in motion.
Her private activities are of no concern.

Students pass around a dictionary covered in messy scribbles with interest. The brown and black swirls form an abstract shape – a bear, perhaps. One of their number, impatient and bored, has been doodling in the margins instead of studying.
Clearly the students appreciate such enthusiastic endeavors.
This abstract thinking may prove a useful skill.
The Good Doctor and the Shawnee
As Dr Rizal's canoe comes to rest on the riverbank, he is greeted by Shawnee people, eager to know what news he has heard from other boats on the river.
Talk about the news from elsewhere.

After seizing a ruby mine, several soldiers load raw gems into crates packed with straw and sawdust, securing each load with a weighty lock. This wealth could shift the balance of power in these lands or back home.
Prepare to transport the rubies homeward.
Use the stones to buy local favor.

A clever corsair has been ravaging a major shipping lane with his forged letters of marque. Even the shrewdest of merchants have fallen sway to the brigand’s silver tongue. {1_CIVILIZATION_ADJ} allies are calling for retribution, but such a calculating mind is a rare asset.
Issue letters patent to license his actions.

{1_CIVILIZATION_ADJ} spies have uncovered a ledger, stitched into the false binding of a merchant’s logbook. The records reveal a black market flourishing in the dark. Beneath the port authority’s blind eye, fortune and vice breed in the shadows.
License privateers to reap the plunder.

The crowd jostles for a glimpse of a notorious pirate queen as she stands to receive her verdict. Her guilt surprises no one, but when she pleads the belly the court falls silent. Mercy and justice stand waiting.
A reprieve of her sentence will satisfy the people.
Justice cares only for law and deed.

A captain angrily wipes the markers off his map, nerves frayed by the war and the glaring weakness of his inexperienced crew. A confederation of raiders have offered to defend the coasts, but those who thrive on chaos rarely prove reliable.
Chaos can be an effective strategy.
Trust is worth a tidy investment.

Privateers have unearthed a gilded reliquary buried by the recently departed enemy. A religious order demands its return, claiming it once housed their sacred texts. The privateers scoff – currency is the one true god.
Offer it as a token to the faithful.
Auction the vessel to the richest zealot.

The {1_CIVILIZATION_ADJ} fleet has finally captured a notorious fortune hunter. Shackles around his ankles restrain his stride, not his swagger. Through a broken grin, the captain makes an offer – his ship, his fighters, and his knowledge of enemy coastlines for his freedom.
His loyalty must be absolute and unwavering.
The gibbet will make him an example to {1_CIVILIZATION_ADJ} enemies.

Just before the cart drives out from under him, a condemned pirate hurls a necklace into the crowd, proclaiming it holds the secret to a lost treasure. None have cracked the charm's cryptogram, but whispers of the hidden fortune now echo through loading docks and seaside inns.
Dismiss the legend as a hoax.
Send an agent to investigate in foreign ports.

A seasoned privateer sails with a growing fleet, and rumors now swirl that they convert raiders into revolutionaries. The magistrates are of two minds: bind the rogue’s loyalty with naval honors, or slit the seed of rebellion with a knife in the dark.
Devotion cannot be forced, but it can be owed.
Their downfall will steel the navy’s resolve.
{1_reward} on Naval Units, but all Privateers take 25 Damage.

From city to city, the agent hears conflicting tales of the rogue’s hoard. One clue emerges – a cave near the shore, hidden under the tide. Fruitless searches take up the days until a single grotto remains. With a thrust into the mud, the shovel strikes metal. A creaking, battered chest surrenders its treasure at last.

A child playing on the riverbank hears a creature skitter into the brush. Curious, she creeps across the mangrove roots, her sharp eyes spotting a crab on a tree trunk. She waves in greeting; the crab dances in response.
The world is full of wonders.
Crabs are good for one thing only – a feast.

A seasoned cowrie collector empties her meager catch onto the sand, cursing the coral and its selfish crevices. Sifting through the shells, a burst of color catches her eye. One cowrie encircled with orange lies nestled among the white. Perhaps the coral is not so cruel after all.
Offer the ring cowry for a fortune telling.
Sell the rare find at market.
An artisan eyes their dwindling stack of turtle shells, lamenting the orders for prized lacquerware they cannot fulfill. If the turtle harvests cannot meet demand, a substitute may need to be found.
Raise prices for the rare crafts.
Reward compliant sailors with high-quality provisions.

{1_CIVILIZATION_ADJ} vintners are suffering from the rising demand for pitch. Without a proper seal to their casks, the wine quickly loses its quality and with it their profits. Local shipbuilders consider their own needs paramount: a sinking vessel takes all its cargo, wine included, to the depths.
Designate a portion of the pitch harvest to the vintners.
